Situation1: They have a serious conversation about financial or health decisions that require full transparency and mutual understanding.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Story: I sit at the kitchen table, laptop open, half-listening to my wife as she brings up the medical bills we’ve been avoiding. She wants us to be honest, to lay everything out—what we can afford, what we can’t, what scares us. I know she needs my full attention, my openness, but my phone keeps buzzing with Slack messages. The product manager is asking for my feedback on the new feature specs, and the design document deadline is tonight. Other teams are waiting on my technical input to move forward, and I can’t let them down. My mind is split: one part wants to close the laptop and look my wife in the eye, to be the partner she needs right now; the other part is calculating how much time I have before the team’s progress stalls. I feel the pressure mounting from both sides, my chest tight with the fear of disappointing someone I care about—at home or at work.
